comment.narrative:
National Adaptation Programme of Action of 2007.

Limited national institutional capacity for effective early warning system and scenario planning for climate change adaptation for the 8 pilot areas.
Weak weather forecasting capacity as a technical barrier to adaptation

1. 960 farmers (120 per distirct) and 56 staff (7 per district) to be trained in early warning systems 2. Operationalization 8 Automatic Weather Stations 3. Undertake policy dialogues at national, provincial and district levels (4 at provincial, 1 per district and 2 national) 4. Construction of saddle dam at sinkapu dam

1. 60 staff members and 1, 218 farmers (656 Females and 562 Males have been trained in early warning systems and are using the knowledge to plan for livelihood activities including farmers 2. 8 Automatic Weather Stations are operation and are transmission 3. 2 National Policy dialogues were undertaken and a policy brief has been developed and validated for consideration in policy and planning under the Ministry of Agriculture. The Policy Dialogue output is being used to speed up revised National Agriculture Policy 4. Saddle dam has been completed and the completion certificate has been issued.

description.narrative: Strengthening the coordination and management of the engendered and rights-based multi-sectoral and decentralised response to HIV&AIDS through support to re-alignment of Response Coordination to Local Authorities.
Strengthening a coordinated, harmonised and sustainable HIV&AIDS Response and Management
populated place
Health - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1) Support to National Strategic Plan Development and implementation 2) Integration of gender, HIV and Health issues into ESIAs for large capital projects 3) Addressing barriers to service provision for key populations, cities responses

1. The revised national AIDS Strategic Framework (NASF) was launched in 2015. A new NASF for the years 2017 to 2021 will be developed in 2016.
2. With technical and financial support from UNDP to the National AIDS Council working with the Zambia Environmental Management Agency, the Road Development Agency and Government in general, Zambia has developed comprehensive guidelines to support the utilisation of HIV, Gender and Human Rights resources allocated through capital road projects. The percentage contained in the guideline goes up to 5% of project cost depending on the evidence and type of HIV/AIDS response required on the ground. This new guideline has already been applied and being implemented at subnational levels. This has resulted in increased domestic resources made available for HIV and AIDS response at sub national levels”.
3. Support toward the dissemination of the Global Commissions report on HIV and AIDS continued. in 2015, UNDP with support from RSC supported the capacity building on the Human Rights Commission to address issues of key population.

independent political entity

Number of leaders and staff with supervisory capacity in Cabinet Office trained based on identified priorities under the capacity development plan

comment.narrative: Absence of integrated public service Capacity Development Plan and a roll out strategy
Draft strategy for the standardization of policy planning, implementation and monitoring developed, taking into consideration the gap analysis and mapping completed in 2014.

Strategy has been completed and has been going analysis by Cabinet Office to identify priority areas for implementation. This process considered the main three components of the report: (i) Gap Analysis (ii) Proposed standardised framework for coordination, and (iii) Implementation arrangements. The workshop identified two options (areas), namely (i) Enhancing the Capacity of Cabinet Office, and (ii) Establishing a new coordinating agency. A working group was appointed to deliberate further on the two options and prepare a detailed position paper for submission to Cabinet Office.

title.narrative: Support to the Human Rights Co

description.narrative: Domestication of International Instruments
independent political entity
Human rights affairs
Baseline Survey on Zambia’s Ratification and Domestication of International HR Instruments

comment.narrative: Baseline survey does not exist

(i) Draft Bill on the Criminalisation of Torture developed. (ii) Public Engagement and Advocacy Strategy on Criminalisation of Torture developed. (iii) HRC Education Manual (iv) HRC Communication Strategy developed. (v) Conduct baseline survey on Zambia’s Ratification and Domestication of International HR Instruments

(i) A high level symposium was held in March with a resolution to expedite the criminalization of torture. Countrywide consultative workshops have been jointly held by the Human Rights Commission and the Zambia Law Development Commission to get views on criminalizing torture. (ii) Public Engagement and Advocacy Strategy on Criminalisation of Torture has been developed and operationalized. The campaign brought together a number of stakeholders including government, law enforcement agencies, civil society, private sector, the church, and parliamentarians, all acknowledging that torture exists in Zambia and there is need to criminalise the scourge. Parliamentary Committee on Legal Affairs, Governance, Human Rights, Gender Matters and Child Affairs conducted its meetings and public hearings on ‘Causes and Extent of Torture in Zambia’. The committee submitted its report to the National Assembly with recommendations which included the following; (i) the country fully domesticates the UNCAT through provisions clearly defining torture and specifically stating acts constituting torture both in the Constitution and subsequently in the relevant statues; (ii) the Government of Zambia to demonstrate commitment to the elimination of torture by lifting the reservation and recognising the competence of the Committee against Torture; and (iii) the Government should urgently strengthen the public sensitisation programmes being undertaken under the Human Rights Commission on what amounts to torture in order to empower the citizens to claim their rights. (iii) The Education Manual has been drafted and is being finalised. (iv) Communication strategy has been developed and HRC staff have undergone training in the use of the strategy for both internal and external communication. (v) Baseline survey to be conducted the following year.

1. JCTR staff trained in Human Rights Based Approach (HRBA) and in Results Based Management (RBM) Staff in the 10 Provincial Planning Units and key staff selected districts trained in HRBA and RBM.
2. MPs and National Assembly Staff trained on the use of tools to monitor implementation of international instruments that Zambia has acceded to.

1. 20 JCTR staff were trained in September in HRBA and RBM as well as going through Training of Trainers. A total of 150 Provincial Planning Units and key staff have been trained in HRBA and RBA in all the 10 provinces. Further all outreach teams in the six districts - Livingstone, Monze, Mongu, Kabwe, Ndola and Kasama have undergone training in HRBA and RBA.
2. Monitoring tools by Parliament/MPs on the implementation of international instruments have been developed. 21 MPs and 2 staff of the National Assembly were trained on the use of these tools.

1. National Assembly of Zambia Strategic Plan finalised, launched and implemented. 2. National Assembly of Zambia Staff trained in Results Based Management.

1. The 2015-2019 Strategic Plan for the National Assembly was finalised, approved, and launched by the Hon Speaker in June, and implementation commenced immediately. Implementation of the Strategic Plan has led to the National Assembly better position itself in discharging its core functions. NAZ has strengthened its capacity by undertaking the following; (i) formation and capacity building of the Strategic Plan Implementation Committee; (ii) Development of the Strategic Plan Implementation Plan; and (iii) Development of the Monitoring and Evaluation Framework for the Strategic Plan (this framework includes performance management framework).
2. Capacity building for staff in Results Based Management was conducted in September and 35 key staff were trained.

title.narrative: Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to the Government of Zambia 2012 - 2015

description.narrative: The Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to Government of Zambia 2012-2015 is aimed at enhancing the attainment of the national development results embodied in the GRZ’s SNDP and the UNDP/GRZ CPAP.
independent political entity

1. MDG Acceleration Plan focusing on poverty and unemployment; 2013 MDG Progress Report for Zambia; and 2013 Zambia Human Development Report.
2. National Accounts, Input-Output and Social Accounting Matrices with gender disaggregated data and environment accounting systems.
3. Database of viable, bankable and affordable appraised public investment projects.

comment.narrative:
1. The country has no MDG Acceleration Plan focusing on poverty and unemployment; 2011 MDG Progress Report for Zambia exists and will be updated to include current development trends; and 2011 Zambia Human Development Report exists and will be updated to show current HDI for Zambia.
2. National Accounts, Input-Output and Social Accounting Matrices does not include gender disaggregated data and environment accounting systems.
3. The country does not have a database of viable, bankable and affordable appraised public investment projects.

1) Conduct in-house training on Public Investment Project Appraisal System for the Ministry of Finance - Zambia 2) Finalize, launch and disseminate the Zambia Human Development Report 2014 which is now ZHDR 2015 3) Produce, launch and disseminate the MDG Comprehensive Review Report

1) The Final technical report and manual for Public Investment Project Appraisal System for the MOF was developed following the stakeholder validation workshop held on 16 January 2015. Training on Public Investment Project Appraisal System and Implementation Analysis was held from 12 to 16 October 2015.
2) The draft 2015 ZHDR was finalised and subjected to a stakeholder review meeting in October 2015. The Report is currently undergoing technical editing in readiness for printing.
3) Following Zambia's adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals, a Comprehensive Review of the MDGs was undertaken to provide insight on the country's progress on MDGs since 2000. A draft report was produced and subjected to stakeholder review.

title.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning syst

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Zambia for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change

title.narrative: Early Warning Systems Project 2014 Initial Annual Work Plan
Strengthening climate information and early warning syst

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Zambia for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate to climate change
1. Score of the capacity assessment as per scorecard 2. number of automatic and manual weather instruments procured, installed and functional.

comment.narrative: 1. Capacity scorecard rating of 80 across men and women (includes functional capacities for agencies to both monitor and forecast climate-related hazard information, share and package such information with relevant agencies, disseminate both warnings and advisories based on such information and provide appropriate legal and procedural frameworks) 2. 0 automatic weather station and 0 manual instruments in the targeted districts

1. Procurement of 28 Automatic Weather Stations finalized 2. Instruments for rehabilitation of manual stations procured and 39 manual stations rehabilitated 3. Zambia Meteorological Department Staff skills upgraded in weather fore casting and climatology -12 in diploma in weather forecasting and 4 Degree in Climatology. 4. Baseline study for the strengthening the early warning system conducted

1. The procurement of 28 Automatic Weather Stations (AWSs) has been completed and the equipment was delivered to the Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD). An Engineer from ADCON provided onsite training for ZMD Staff at one of the project sites in Gwembe and installed one AWS which is now operational. The remaining 27 AWSs will be installed in 2016.
2. Procurement of the instruments for rehabilitation of manual stations has been finalized and delivery will be expected in the first quarter of 2016.
3. Sponsorship of the 12 Zambia Meteorological Department staff to study Diploma in Weather Forecasting and 3 to study Degree in Climatology is underway. University/College fees and student allowances paid for for the current semester/term
4. Baseline Study has been completed and has provided information on the capacity development needs. The outputs of this study are the baseline survey results, revised project outputs and activities, an updated monitoring and evaluation plan, and a process report which will be useful for follow up activities.

description.narrative: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Zambia.

1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

comment.narrative:
1. Average capacity scorecard rating of 80 across men and women (see Annex 5 of project document).
2. Annual budget of: US$322,680 allocated to ZMD; and US$614,057 allocated to DMMU.

1. Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 171 for both men and women (see Annex 5 of project document).
2. 20% increase in annual domestic finance allocated to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

This development objective is on-track. There has been capacity enhancement in climate information generation, packaging and dissemination since the project commenced.
1. ZMD's capacity score has increased from 80 to 105 out of 171. This has been achieved through training of staff of the implementing entities. Eight officers from the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAL) who were managing weather stations without any formal training in meteorology have been trained in meteorological observation and interpretation, and are therefore now able to interpret and simplify weather information for use by local farming communities. Twenty-two officers from the Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD) have undergone a refresher course in meteorological codes, compiling of climate information, and packaging of weather and climate information. This has improved capacities for climate information production, packaging and dissemination at district level. Also, twenty officers from ZMD were trained as enumerators for the CIEWS national baseline survey. This enumeration course empowered the meteorological staff to engage with communities on the application of climate information. This has contributed to the staff providing and interpreting weather information for use by local communities, which they in turn are using to plan their livelihood activities such as farming and fishing. Thirty ZMD staff have received training in software applications that will enable them to improve data management at the weather stations, and they have also been provided with new high-capacity computer hardware. Furthermore, ZMD has benefited from two advisor missions during the period under review. The first mission was by the CIRDA Chief Technical Advisor on Alternative Technologies, who built ZMD’s capacity in Early Warning System design. The second mission was by the UNDP RSC Programme Specialist for Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change, who collaborated with ZMD to assess the equipment and staffing requirements for data rescue.
2. There has been a 50% increase in domestic finance allocated to ZMD for early warning systems in the period under review, from a budget of 322,680 USD in the baseline year. This is due to advocacy by ZMD and the Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) on the importance of early warning systems to safeguard lives, livelihoods, property and infrastructure.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of Zambia Meteorological Department to monitor and forecast extreme weather and climate change.

1. Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network (fully operational).
2. Frequency data transmission and reception.

comment.narrative:
1. Automatic: 0% of districts; Manual: 0% of districts.
2. At present, the 2 AWSs transmit data which is sent daily
The majority of manual stations record data at (GMT) 06h00, 09h00, 12h00, 15h00. However, provision to ZMD does not occur daily.

1. Automatic: 29% of districts;
Manual 37% of districts.
2. 30 AWSs (28 new, 2 rehabilitated), transmitting continuously
39 rehabilitated manual stations collecting data at the synoptic hours of (GMT) 06h00, 09h00, 12h00, 15h00, 18h00 and 00h00, and sending to ZMD daily.

This outcome is on-track.
1. At the start of the project, Zambia Meteorological Department had a network of 39 manual weather stations that were each missing some instruments and two automatic weather stations that had been vandalized. The manual weather stations are to be rehabilitated in the second half of 2015, as the instruments are under procurement. The target of 29% of districts having automatic weather stations has already been exceeded, as 19 stations have been installed through co-financing from the Southern African Science Service Centre for Climate Change and Adaptive Land Use (SASSCAL), 5 through co-financing from the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) and 8 by the UNDP-GEF Climate Change Adaptation project with the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. Thus, the network of automatic weather stations has expanded from 2 to 32. This brings the current percentage of districts having automatic weather stations to 31%. This will be increased further to 58% with the installation of 28 additional automatic weather stations by the CIEWS project in the second half of 2015, as the equipment is under procurement.
2. This modernization of the observing network has enabled real-time observation of current weather conditions. Timeliness of data transmission and exchange has been improved, as the automatic weather stations provide data at 15-minute intervals, 24 hours per day. Furthermore, the accuracy of weather forecasts has been enhanced.

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for making early warnings and long-term development plans.

1. Percentage of population in Chipata, Gwembe and Sesheke Districts with access to improved climate-related flood and drought warnings (disaggregated by gender).
2. Development frameworks and disaster policies that integrate climate information in the formulation.
3. Sector-specific, tailored climate information packages that integrate climate risks.

comment.narrative:
1. 0% of men
0 % of women.
2. The Sixth National Development Plan highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies, but not the need for improved information to inform the strategies.
3. ZMD, in collaboration with the relevant line ministries, produces sector-specific forecasts for agriculture, aviation, water and health.

1. 100 % of men;
100 % of women.
2. At least the Seventh National Development Plan to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period.
3. Sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced for agriculture, aviation, water, health , tourism, construction, road and rail transport, and energy

This outcome is on-track.
1. At the start of the project, there was minimal evidence of application of hydrological, meteorological and environmental information by individual Zambians in their livelihood activities. The CIEWS project has conducted awareness-raising activities in the three CIEWS pilot districts, ten other climate-vulnerable districts and the ten provincial capitals. Preliminary results from a recent national survey conducted by the CIEWS project has revealed that approximately 30% of those surveyed, in 30 districts across the country, now apply weather and climate information in planning their livelihood activities, particularly fishing and farming. This information is disseminated to them through radio, television, print media and the internet. The project has contributed to enhancing public information on climate change, as well as enhanced capacity of ZMD for web management so that up-to-date weather information is made available to the general public. For further information see www.zmd.gov.zm. A CIEWS project brochure is also available on this website.
2. The Seventh National Development Plan is under development and its theme will be inclusive green growth, in recognition of the impacts of climate change. Currently, there is training for planners in all vulnerable key sectors on climate change mainstreaming and national adaptation planning.
3. ZMD is providing more timely and accurate tailored information to the aviation sector (daily flight forecasts) and agricultural sector (10-day crop weather bulletins, available on ZMD website, www.zmd.gov.zm, and distributed to farmers). Tailored information for agriculture has contributed to the small scale farmers receiving appropriate information in good time to be used for planning. For other sectors, tailored information is provided on request. This has been enabled through institutional strengthening, by providing modern equipment and training.

description.narrative: To reduce people's vulnerability from the risk of climate change and man-made disasters and environmental degradation
independent political entity
1. Policies and legal frameworks for agriculture, forestry and land take into account climate change issues 2. NAP and NAMAs foragriculture, energy, industry and waste management sectors in place

comment.narrative: 1. The Draft Forest Policy has been reviewed to take into account climate change but the Act has not been reviewed 2.The draft NCCRS, but not its implementation plans have been developed 3. The CCFU has been the interim mechanism for coordinating climate change adaption and mitigation efforts

The targets for 2015 are: 1. finalize climate change financing framework 2. Develop National Adaptation Plans framework 3. Develop Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDC) 4. Develop the implementation plan for the climate change policy

As of end of third quarter, the following have been achieved 1.Intended Nationally Determined Contributions completed. The INDC identifies Sustainable Forest Management, sustainable agriculture and renewable energy and energy efficiency as key sectors that will drive Zambia towards low carbon resilient development. 2. National Adaptation Plan framework developed. The NAP framework provides a framework for developing adaptation projects in Zambia an source of funding for this projects

title.narrative: PIM4625 Strenthening mgt. & genrating env benefits of PA

description.narrative: Strengthening Management Effectiveness and Generating Multiple Environmental Benefits within and around the Greater Kafue National Park and West Lunga National Park in Zambia
PIMS4625 Strengthening Management and Generating Multiple Environment Benefits
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Sustainable Land and Forest Management established in Miombo Woodland and Dry Evergreen Forest ecosystems in Protected Area (PA) Core areas and Community managed Game Management Areas (GMAs) and conservancies enabling forest corridor connectivity between West Lunga National Park (WLNP) and Kfue National Park (KNP) in the long term

comment.narrative: Biodiversity and carbon sinks of Kafue/West Lunga in Zambia are better protected from threats and effectively managed by local institutions, communities, and economic actors using sustainable forestry and land management practices

1. Strategy for improved management effectiveness and increased revenues of Kafue National and West Lunga National Parks developed. 2. Management operations (patrolling, wildlife monitoring, fire control, support to Community Based Natural Resources Management (CBNRM) ) and performance effectiveness strengthened 3. CBNRM support unit established at Kafue National Park business centre to facilitate CBNRM activities. 4. Project Implementation Unit established and functional

1. The consultant to the develop the stragey for improved management effectiveness and increased revenues of Kafue National and West Lunga National Parks has been recruited and commenced the preparation of the strategy. 2. Support to Management Operations has commenced in the selected 14 sites while the project is all building the capacity of the 14 Community Resource Boards in Project Sites. 3. CBNRM Coordinator and 2 Project Officers have been recruited 4. The Project Manager has been recruited

description.narrative: Biodiversity and carbon sinks of Greater Kafue / West Lunga in Zambia are better protected from threats and effectively managed by local institutions, communities, and economic actors using sustainable forestry and land management practices.

Sustainable Land and Forest Management established in Miombo Woodland and Dry Evergreen Forest ecosystems in PA Core areas and Community managed GMAs and conservancies enabling forest corridor connectivity between WLNP and KNP in the long term

comment.narrative:
24,164 km2
(PA Core areas)

24,164 km2 PA+ 41,297 km2 GMAs
= 65,461 km2
(Target GMAs consisting of Mumbwa, Namwala, Mufunta, Kasonso-Busanga, and Lunga-Luswishi in Greater Kafue NP, and Lukwawa, Musele- Matembo and Chibwika-Ntambu in West Lunga Management Area)

This development target is on course, so far, Kafue National Park (KNP) (22,480 sq. km) and West Lunga National Park (WLNP)(1,684 sq. km) in terms of initial efforts to put in place an effective system to remove threats such as poaching and protecting the biodiversity . This has been through enhanced law enforcement, fire management, research to manage the carnivores, infrastructure development to support law enforcement, tourism and monitoring. This has contributed to the increase in animal population, particularly the elephants and buffalos, (KNP Annual Report 2014). In WLNP, a similar situation has occurred where more elephant and buffalo sighting have been reported (WLNP Ecological Monitoring Report, 2014). Furthermore WLNP and Lukwakwa GMA have been designated as an Important Bird Area (Birdlife International 2014). The project contribution has been mainly through community awareness raising activities on the need to conserve the natural resources and remove the threats to biodiversity.
Regarding the Game Management Areas (Musele-Matebo,Chibwika-Ntambo and Lukwakwa, Kasonso Busanga, Lunga Luswishi), comprising a total area of 28,910 square km against the target of 41,297 square km have been brought under improved management. This comprises 70% of the targeted area. The improved management has been through strengthening the Community Based Natural Resources Management (CBNRM), through the village scouts and promoting sustainable livelihoods (fish farming, beekeeping, conservation farming and agro forestry). This has contributed to improved resources management and communities are in the process of establishing the conservancies in open areas.
The contribution of the project was through strengthening CBNRM.

description.narrative: Increased management effectiveness and financial sustainability of Greater Kafue and West Lunga PA system
1. Increase in Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool;

comment.narrative:
57% KNP (METTPAZ 2010)
39% KNP GMAs (2010)
28% WLNP (2010)
20% WLNP GMAs (2010)

65% KNP
45% KNP GMAs
40% WLNP
30% WLNP GMAs

Although a lot more still needs to be done, this target is on course as the score of Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METTPAZ) of 59 and 30 (Zambia Wildlife Report, 2014) against the target of 65% and 40% respectively. This has been through enhanced law enforcement, fire management, research to manage the carnivores, infrastructure development to support law enforcement, tourism and monitoring. This has contributed to the increase in animal population, particularly the elephants and buffalos, (KNP Annual Report 2014). In WLNP, a similar situation has occurred where more elephant and buffalo sighting have been reported (WLNP Ecological Monitoring Report, 2014). Furthermore WLNP and Lukwakwa GMA have been designated as an Important Bird Area (Birdlife International 2014). The project contribution has been mainly through community awareness raising activities on the need to conserve the natural resources and remove the threats to biodiversity.

KNP=8.6% of carrying capacity (as per aerial survey 2008)
KNP=56% (1.252 mill ha)
KNP=1,650,000 CO2 annually from late fires

12% of carrying capacity in both KNP and productive GMAs
KNP=reduced by 50% (625,800 ha)
KNP=825,000t CO2 reduced emissions annually
Not undertaken. The activities to achieve these indicators will be undertake in the subsequent years

description.narrative: 3. Reduction in funding gap of the targeted National Parks moving up one category (based on REMNPAS financial viability assessment) with at least one new PPP formed (WLNP)

comment.narrative: 0 PPP in Greater KNP and WLNP. revenues: approx $600,000 in KNP

At least 1 PPP in each of core PAs of Greater WLNP and KNP
at least $850,000 revenues in KNP
(increase by 10% per annum)

This target is on track.There has been an improvement in the revenue for the KNP from USD 600,000 to USD 750,000. This is due to the increased animal population (elephant, lion, cheetah and buffalo), improved park infrastructure (roads, air strips and lodges) to the park and improved marketing (KNP Annual Report 2014).
The project's contribution has been through community awareness in GMAs surrounding KNP on the need to conserve wildlife.

description.narrative: 4. PES maintaining watershed / river catchments by communities in KNP benefitting ZESCO

comment.narrative: 1 PES in KNP with ZESCO
The status quo at the time of design is still obtaining as no activities have been undertaken yet to contribute to this.

description.narrative: Sustainable land and forest management by “Community Conservancies” in GMA buffer areas through selected CBNRM practices.

1a. “Community Conservancies” established
1b. VAGs legally established
1c.ILUA plans completed for all VAGs
1d. Women members in VAGs and improved livelihoods

comment.narrative: 0 ha, 0, No ILUAs in place for VAGs (0), Negligible women representation in governance structure in VAG areas

557, 900 ha (5,579 km2) of intact forest ecosystems established as community conservancies in targeted GMAs. At least 25 Village Action Groups (VAGs) in target areas formally recognized and constituted by Y2 with clear resource rights, delineation of legally recognized VAG boundaries and use zones, management structures and benefit sharing plans (in line with national REDD+ criteria). Integrated Land Use Assessment plans developed for all VAGs. At least 40% female representation in all elected VAGs in project area; increased per capita / household income compared to 2012 baseline

This target is on course. Sustainable land and forest management by Community Conservancies in GMA buffer areas through selected CBNRM practices
Sustainable land and forest management by the communities is progressing though at a low rate. So far, 188,128 ha (in Sanje Local Forest in Mumbwa and Lunda National Forest in Mwinilunga) are being managed sustainably with the involvement of local communities against the target of 557,900 ha. This is 34% of the target. The promoting sustainable livelihoods (beekeeping and conservation farming) tree planting and sustainable utilisation of the forest products and enhanced law enforcement (North Western and Central Province Provincial Forest Reports 2014).
The contribution of the project has been through community awareness on sustainable utilisation of natural resources.
Regarding the targets on improved governance structures, land use planning and REDD+ the status remains as at the project design.

description.narrative:
2. Conservation farming practices applied in targeted GMAs
Increased yields

comment.narrative: 0 ha using conservation farming techniques

At least 3,760 ha of conservation farming practiced by at least 1,600 HH (in 40 VAGs) by end of project. Introduction of conservation farming practices leads to improved soil organic matter and field intensification across 3,760 hectares leading to: 40% reduction in cumulative CO2 emissions from vegetation clearance for agriculture in targeted areas resulting in 7,520 ha of avoided deforestation in targeted areas, Resulting decrease in direct lifetime avoided t CO2 emissions from clearance of vegetation for agriculture (20 years) in that same landscape = 988,128 tCO2e compared to BAU scenario

This target is on course. Communities in West Lunga game management areas have been mobilized, sensitized and oriented in conservation farming. So far 500 against the target of 1,600 households in 2014/205 farming season are practicing conservation farming. This presents 31% of the target. The productivity of maize for those farmers who are practicing conservation farming have increased from 2 tonnes per hectare to 8 tonnes per hectare per year.

description.narrative: 3. Demonstration of avoided deforestation (no net loss) in at least 25 VAGs establishing REDD pilots linking to national and/or voluntary carbon financing

comment.narrative: 0 ha / no REDD+ pilots in VAGs

25,000 ha leveraging additional 75,000 ha (intact forest) by protecting VAG designated forest zones: - VCS and CCB standard acceptable to international brokers certifying REDD pilots and marketing for carbon financing, Potential buyers identified to purchase the REDD+ carbon credits from the VAG pilots
No change. The activities have not taken place, the have been planned for subsequent quarters

description.narrative: 4. Reduced rate of deforestation from fuel wood extraction in all targeted GMAs

comment.narrative:
Unsustainable firewood collection and SFM governance
- Wood fuel collection in designated areas is ad-hoc and unsustainable
- No sustainable woodlots exist in targeted areas
- Knowledge of coppicing practices for fuel wood extraction among communities in targeted areas is very low

Under the project designated zones for fuel wood collection will be established optimizing SFM (and testing different ‘treatments’)
- Working with the Copperbelt University, the 25 VAGs will be trained in harvesting and coppice management and will each establish an auditable fuel wood use and CFM plan.
- Linked to land use planning, experimental fuel wood management and collection zones will be established in 25 VAGs; systems boundaries for VAGs will be defined; and alternative operational modalities for fuel wood harvesting and use will be applied (including coppicing).
Leading to the following GEBs:
- Direct lifetime avoided emissions savings of 63,281 tCO2e (20 years) compared to fuel wood usage in a BAU scenario
There has been no change as the project focus in the reporting period was on sensitization. The next step would be engaging the communities in the development of land use plans.

description.narrative: 5. Reduced rate of deforestation from late season fires in targeted GMA zones

comment.narrative:
Late season fires and poor fire management monitoring and practices in all targeted GMA zones
- 174,671 ha of forests burned in late-season fires annually in GMA areas in KNP
- 627,088 ha of forests burned in late-season fires annually in PA zones of KNP
- Annual estimated CO2 emissions from fire in GMA zones of KNP = 230,566 tCO2e per annum
- Annual estimated CO2 emissions from fire in PA parts of KNP = 827,756 tCO2e per annum

Land use and forest conservation plans will be developed and adopted by all VAGs, supported and monitored by Kafue Central Business Unit (CBU)
- Forest and wildlife patrolling and protection will be done by Village Scouts in all targeted GMAs
- Fire control action plans will be adopted and put in use in all VAGs
- As a result fire losses will be reduced by at least 30% in GMA zones annually through fire protection practices (boundary and firebreak management, early burning, etc), land use planning, patrolling and education
The resulting direct lifetime avoided t CO2 emissions (over 20 years) from these activities compared to a BAU scenario (in GMA zones) = 1,383,394 tCO2e

There has been no change as the project focus in the reporting period was on sensitization. The next step would be engaging the communities in undertaking fire management through the Village Actions Groups

description.narrative: Promoting innovative, inclusive and equitable growth in peri-urban areas of Zambia
Promoting innovative, inclusive and equitable growth in peri-urban areas of Zambia (Innovate for Inclusive Growth Project)

(a) % of jobs created by SMEs in targeted clusters (b) # of targeted policies revised to address context-specific SMEs growth inhibitors and income inequality based on evaluations of policies, strategies and programmes (c) # of diagnostic priority sector studies conducted (d) % of SMEs with products that meet agreed national standards. (e) % of total investments by SMEs in technological upgrading for production enhancement (f) % of functional technical centres of excellence/innovation hubs established to support SMEs (g) Status of project dashboard, risks and issues management (h) % delivery of project activities and resources (i) Proportion (%) of project results performance attainment based on project evaluation reports

comment.narrative: (a) Labour survey 2010 (b) MSMEs Policy 2006 (c) Diagnostic studies for at least two (2) sector (leather and fruits/vegetables) have been conducted (d) Indicator survey 2014 to document adherence by SMEs to quality standards (e) Indicator survey 2014 to document investment ratio by SMEs in technology and innovation (f) 1 - progress has been made on the technical centre of excellence/innovation hubs for leather and leather products which is still operational (g) Updated project dashboard (h) Above 70 % on mobilized and committed resources (i) Mid Term Review of CPAP 2011-2015

a) Final draft industrial policy developed b) Tailor made capacity building programmes in SQAM developed for targeted SMEs c) Review and implementation of the value chain core venture based cluster programmes commenced d) Feasibility studies for the establishment of a technical packaging center commenced

a)A draft industrial policy was finalized and presented to key stakeholders and line Ministries who have responded with feedback for consideration by the MCTI. The Ministry is planning for the consolidation of the Industrial Policy and also develop an Implementation plan. b)A SQAM needs assessment was conducted in Mongu which 9 SMEs participated in from the Mango, Timber, Dairy, metal fabrication, Carpentry and Leather Sectors.A Tailor made capacity building plan on SQAM was developed and awaiting a SQAM training targeting 30 SMEs. c)The Zambia Development Agency (ZDA) conducted a Gemstone Lapidary and Processing (GPL) training workshop in Lundazi. A total of 50 SMEs attended the 15 day theoretical and hands-on workshop. d) A consultative meeting with key stakeholders was held in Kabwe to conceptualize the setting up a first of its kind Technical Packaging Centre TPC in Zambia.

title.narrative: Capacity Development of the Extractive sector in Zambia

description.narrative: Capacity Development of the Extractive (mining) sector in Zambia

The overall objective of the project is to develop a five year multi partner programme for implementing mining sector transformational activities to achieve the Vision 2030, leveraging its commitment to the AMV.
Mining sector policy revised to conform to the AMV Availability of evidence to support the review of the Mining sector policies and strategy

comment.narrative: 1. Limited awareness among stakeholders on the African Mining Vision 2. Lack of consensus on the gaps, issues, weaknesses on the attractive sector's management in Zambia. 3. Limited understanding of the capacity of Government and other key stakeholder to implement the mining sector development priorities in line with the country’s Vision 2030 and AMV

1. Constitute and engage the Project Steering Committee (Project Board). 2. Agree on the Project Quarterly Work Plans 2015 and Annual Work Plan 2016. 3. Begin the Communication and Advocacy support to sensitize different stakeholders about the AMV. 4. Commence the review of how the national policies (strategies) and legislation align with the AMV.

1. Project Steering Committee (Project Board) was constituted and engaged at the Orientation Retreat. 2. The Project Quarterly Work Plans 2015 was developed with the Ministry of Mines and Annual Work Plan 2016 was developed at the Orientation Retreat. 3. The Communication and Advocacy support to sensitize different stakeholders about the AMV was begun at the Extractive Industries Side Event, which was organised at the UN Sustainable Development Summit in New York in September. 4. Two consultants were engaged to conduct an assessment to review and assess the extent to which national policies (strategies) and legislation align with the AMV. The assessment is ongoing, expected to be completed at the end of December 2015.
